awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Tectonic controls on arc evolution and petrogenesis, central Sierra Nevada Ancestral Cascades arc, California
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent studies of active volcanoes show that volcanic eruptions are often triggered by earthquakes, which occur in response to plate tectonic forces. But the active faults on such volcanoes cannot be directly examined as they are deeply buried by sediments and earlier erupted volcanic materials. The PIs of this study have discovered three Miocene-age volcanic centers in eastern California, in a region called the Walker Lane that, through uplift and erosion, have exposed the rarely-seen roots of Cascade volcanoes. Their work has both scientific and societal broader impacts. First, because the active Lassen Volcanic Center in northern California is also in the Walker Lane region, their proposed work will be directly applicable to understanding eruption triggering mechanisms there, and at other active Cascade volcanoes. Their recent work has also uncovered the largest volcanic eruption rates known in either the modern or ancient Cascades,  and their new work will delimit the tectonic conditions that allow for very large volcanic eruptions to occur. In addition, the PIs will be training a new generation of scientists. Fresno State undergraduate students will be involved in all aspects of the work. They are mostly first generation college students, and are often from under-represented groups and low income families. This NSF support is crucial to bringing research experiences to an underserved community. Through the Fresno State-University of California Davis collaboration, Fresno State students will have the opportunity to collaborate with a PhD student as well as undergraduate field and lab assistants at UC Davis. Students will take the lead not only on research projects, but on presentations at professional meetings, and will be co-authors or lead authors on papers. Most Fresno State students will also serve California's Central Valley as Geologists after graduation, working on projects that range from earthquake hazards to groundwater quality. This early support for their research experiences thus pays dividends to the Central Valley many years after the grant is over. The project is supported by both the Petrology & Geochemsitry and Tectonics programs.

The ancestral Cascade volcanoes of central California that the PIs and their students will study are the ancient analogs of active volcanoes, such as Lassen Peak and Mt Shasta in northern California, or Mt. St. Helens in Washington. The ancestral Cascades formed from about 16 to 5 million years ago and have been uplifted at the eastern edge of the Sierra Nevada Mountain range. Uplift and erosion have exposed 5 km of structural relief on three volcanic centers. The PIs will take advantage of these deep exposures to map the geologic faults that allowed these ancestral Cascade volcanoes to develop. Their earlier work showed that volcanoes develop in what are called transtensional basins; the faults that form these basins allow pathways for magmas to reach the surface. Their new geologic maps and age dates will constrain the timing of both fault activity and volcanic eruptions, and will allow a test whether the volume and style (explosive vs. effusive) of volcanic eruptions is directly related to the magnitude of fault activity. One of their hypotheses is that episodes of active transtensional faulting will allow deeper, hotter magmas to be erupted. The PIs will analyze the compositions of the lava flows, and use thermodynamic models, to determine whether the magmas were stored in deep or shallow reservoirs prior to eruption. The PIs have also discovered a suite of lavas that represent the single largest eruption rates ever recorded in either the modern or ancient Cascades. Their new data will determine whether such large eruptions tapped sources that are unusually deep or hot, and whether such episodes are controlled by fault activity. With these results, it may be possible to examine earthquakes at modern volcanoes to predict eruption volume and style.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Earth and Planetary Sciences, University of California Davis

por.por_cntn:
This study focused largely on the Ancestral Cascades arc in the central Sierra Nevada range crest and range front, California, which formed in response to subduction of the Farallon plate in Miocene to Pliocene time (ca. 16 to 4 Ma). This work included detailed geologic mapping, petrographic analysis, 40Ar/39Ar geochronology, whole rock major-and trace-element geochemistry and isotope geochemistry, and mineral chemistry analysis by electron microprobe.

We show that large volcanic centers formed from at releasing fault step-overs of the Walker Lane, an active dextral transtensional fault zone that takes up a fourth of the relative plate motion between the Pacific plate and the North American plate (with the San Andreas fault currently taking up the rest). We have identified and studied four arc volcanic centers in this region:

(1) The Sierra Crest-Little Walker volcanic center (Sonora Pass region), which records the birth of the Walker Lane at 12 Ma. This is the largest (Long Valley-sized) and longest-lived (12 to 5 Ma) volcanic center. Mineral chemistry studies show that it was a transcrustal system with magma storage from upper mantle to upper crustal levels, typical of most arcs globally.  

(2) The Ebbetts Pass volcanic center, which is a smaller (Lassen-sized), more short-lived (6.5 to 4.5 Ma) volcanic center. Mineral chemistry studies show the surprising result that magmas were not transcrustal, but instead resided only at shallow crustal levels. We attribute this to higher rates of transtension, which produced greater tensile stresses in the deep crust, facilitating upward magma transport, rather than allowing residence in deeper crustal storage areas.

(3) The Diamond Valley volcanic center (Markleeville region), where a previously undiscovered silicic caldera formed at a releasing stepover in the Genoa fault at 11.0 +/- 0.06 Ma, showing the antiquity of the fault, which remains active today. The caldera-forming eruption produced the dacite Diamond Valley Tuff, whose outflow is predicted to be regional in extent; indeed, in our most recent mapping, we have discovered its outflow in the next volcanic center to the south, the Leviathan Peak volcanic center.

(4) The Leviathan Peak volcanic center (Monitor Pass region) was active at the same time as the Diamond Valley volcanic center (11.03 +/- 0.14 Ma to 9.84 +/- 0.09 Ma) but then it experienced an unroofing event, followed by a second pulse of magmatism (8.95 +/- 0.05 Ma to 6.72 +/- 0.06 Ma) and a second unroofing event that continues to the present day. Because of these unroofing events, this volcanic center exposes a much higher ratio of intrusive to eruptive rocks (ca. 75:25) than the other three centers (ca. 10:90). We infer that this is the result of the position of this center on the footwall of the Antelope Valley-Slinkard Valley normal fault zone (which most recently slipped in the 2021 M 6.0  Antelope Valley earthquake), while the other three centers formed in the hanging walls of fault zones. Our stratigraphy constrains slip on the Antelope Valley-Slinkard Valley fault zone since 6 Ma, at 1.2 km normal offset.

A second, major collaborative opportunity emerged during the course of this grant: determining the age, geologic setting, and pumice geochemistry of a major fossil treasure trove discovered in the western Sierra Nevada foothills in 2020, which we dub the Miocene Zoo. The Miocene Zoo is a fossil treasure trove with great biodiversity, including mastodons, gomphotheres, camels, rhinos, horses, dogs, rodents, tortoises, turtles, fish, birds, and abundant trees. It captured a great deal of media attention, including articles in Smithsonian Magazine and The Guardian. The diversity in fauna is attributed to a changing climate during the late Miocene, when forests were transitioning to grasslands and species of both ecosystems co-existed. However, the geologic setting and precise age of the Miocene Zoo were unknown prior to our work. Busby built upon her experience with Sierran paleochannels, used to reconstruct the topographic evolution of the Sierra Nevada, to recognize that the Miocene Zoo was deposited in the lower reaches of the Mokelumne paleochannel. New geologic mapping and sedimentological and petrographic analysis reveal that the fossils are preserved within braided stream deposits in the axis of the Mokelumne paleochannel, and that water-lain tephras erupted from the Ancestral Cascades arc (about 100 km upstream) provided the silica for fossilization. We also provided age controls on the fossil treasure trove (8.2 +/- 0.1 Ma), using U-Pb detrital zircon geochronology on tuffaceous sandstones, as well as 40Ar/39Ar geochronology on pumices.

 


Last Modified: 07/05/2024
Modified by: Cathy J Busby
